content.text: Use Fig. 1.1 to determine:
1. the average speed of the train during the 120 s
average speed =   .........
2. the speed of the train at time \(t = 100 \text{s}\)
Describe how the acceleration of the train at time \(t = 100 \text{s}\) differs from the acceleration at time \(t = 20 \text{s}\)
The initial acceleration of the train is \(0.75 \text{m/s}^2\)
Calculate the resultant force that acts on the train at this time
resultant force =   .........
At time \(t = 120 \text{s}\), the train begins to decelerate
State what is meant by _deceleration_
A train of mass \(5.6 \times 10^{5} \text{kg}\) is at rest in a station
At time \(t = 0 \text{s}\), a resultant force acts on the train and it starts to accelerate forwards
Fig. 1.1 is the distance-time graph for the train for the first 120 s
State, in terms of \(P\), the moment of force \(P\) about B
the moment of \(W\) about B
the force \(P\)
the force \(Q\)
Calculate:
Fig. 2.1 shows a uniform plank AB of length 2.0 m suspended from two ropes X and Y
The weight \(W\) of the plank is 210 N. The force in rope X is \(P\). The force in rope Y is \(Q\)
State what is meant by the principle of conservation of energy
State the energy changes that take place from when the girl begins to exert a force on the ball until the ball hits the ground and stops moving

The mass of the ball is \(4.0\mathrm{kg}\). The girl exerts a force on the ball for \(0.60\mathrm{s}\). The speed of the ball increases from \(0\mathrm{m / s}\) to \(12\mathrm{m / s}\) before it leaves the girl's hand
Calculate:
1. the momentum of the ball on leaving the girl's hand
momentum =   .........
2. the average resultant force exerted on the ball
average resultant force =   .........
Fig. 3.1 shows a girl throwing a heavy ball
Fig. 4.1 shows liquid in a cylinder
The depth of the liquid is \(10\mathrm{cm}\) and the radius of the cylinder is \(3.0\mathrm{cm}\). The weight of the liquid in the cylinder is \(2.5\mathrm{N}\)
Calculate the density of the liquid
density =   .........
The difference \(h\) between the two liquid levels is \(2.0 \text{cm}\). The density of the liquid is \(800 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\)
Calculate the difference between the pressure of the gas and atmospheric pressure
pressure difference =   .........
A similar device with a tube of smaller cross-sectional area is connected to a gas supply at the same pressure
State and explain any effect on the value of \(h\)
Fig. 4.2 shows a device that measures the pressure of a gas supply
Fig. 4.2
In the space below, draw a labelled diagram of the structure of a thermocouple thermometer. Include the device from which a reading is taken
A thermocouple thermometer is used to measure the temperature of the flame of a small candle
State two reasons why the thermocouple thermometer is suitable for this application
reducing the diameter of the capillary tube
increasing the volume of the liquid-filled bulb
State and explain any effect on the sensitivity of a liquid-in-glass thermometer of:
State **three** factors that determine the rate of evaporation of water
A person climbs out of a swimming pool and stands in the open air
Explain why evaporation of water from the surface of the person's body causes the person to feel cold
A laser produces a beam of monochromatic light. State what is meant by the term _monochromatic._
The wave undergoes reflection and refraction at the air-glass boundary
On Fig. 7.1 draw:
the wavefronts of the reflected wave
the wavefronts of the refracted wave
A wave, in air, is incident on a glass block. Fig. 7.1 shows the wavefronts at the air-glass boundary. The arrow shows the direction of travel of the wavefronts
A transverse wave is produced in a long, horizontal rope. The rope is much longer than the wavelength of the wave
In the space below, sketch a diagram to show the appearance of the rope as the wave passes along it. Label two important features of the wave
Explain what is meant by the term longitudinal wave
The speed of sound in air is \(330 \text{m/s}\)
State a typical value for the speed of sound in a liquid
Using your value from **(b)**(i), calculate the wavelength of the sound wave in the ocean
wavelength =   .........
The frequency of the sound wave is \(800\mathrm{Hz}\)
A vibrating source on a ship produces a sound wave that travels through the ocean. The wave produced is a longitudinal wave
Two lamps are connected in parallel with the battery. On Fig. 9.1, using the correct symbols, complete the circuit diagram
the current
current =   .........
the power
One of these lamps has a resistance of \(6.0\Omega\)
Calculate, for this lamp:
The power of the other lamp is \(36 \text{W}\)
Calculate the total energy delivered to this lamp in 20 hours
Fig. 9.1 shows the symbol for a \(12\mathrm{V}\) battery
State the name of the metal from which the core is made
Explain why there is a voltage between the two terminals of the secondary coil
There are 560 turns on the primary coil and 910 turns on the secondary coil of the transformer. The voltage between the two terminals of the secondary coil is 78 V
Calculate the voltage supplied by the a.c. generator
generator voltage =   .........
The primary coil of the transformer is connected to the output voltage of an a.c. generator which supplies an alternating current
Transformers are used to increase the voltage when electrical energy is transmitted in cables across long distances
Explain why power losses in the cables are lower when the voltage is high
A transformer consists of two coils of wire wound on a metal core. Fig. 10.1 represents the transformer
Fig. 11.1 shows data about nine elements
Carbon-14 is a radioactive isotope with a nucleon number of 14. It decays by emitting \(\beta\) -particles
Use any data you need from Fig. 11.1 to write down the nuclide equation for this decay
A radioactive sample is placed close to a detector. The radioactive isotope in the sample has a long half-life. The detector records a count rate of 597 counts/s
Fig. 11.2 shows the readings when different materials are placed between the radioactive sample and the detector

table.html:
materialcount rate counts/s
a sheet of paper602
a piece of thin aluminium598
a piece of thin lead510

content.text: Explain whether any \(\alpha\) -particles, \(\beta\) -particles or \(\gamma\) -rays are emitted by the radioactive sample
\(\alpha\) -particles
\(\beta\) -particles
\(\gamma\) -rays
